authors: Nic White For Daily Mail Australia
description: The two-seater aircraft slammed into a the ground near Barkers Lodge Road in the suburb of Oakdale in Sydney's southwest outskirts, killing its male pilot. The cause of the crash is not yet known.
title: Pilot dies in ultralight plane crash near Sydney
title_page: Pilot dies in ultralight plane crash near Sydney | Daily Mail Online
text:
A man is dead after his ultralight plane crashed into a field on the southwest outskirts of Sydney.
The two-seater Drifter Fisher Mark I Sport slammed into a the ground near Barkers Lodge Road in the rural suburb of Oakdale, west of Campbelltown, at about 4.20pm on Friday.
The pilot, who owned the aircraft since 2009, was believed to be the only one on board. The cause of the crash is not yet known.
Scroll down for video
A man is dead after his ultralight plane crashed into a field on the southwest outskirts of Sydney
The pilot was believed to be the only one on board. The cause of the crash is not yet known
Four crews from Fire and Rescue NSW are on their way to the scene and the Australian Transport Safety Bureau is investigating.
Recreational Avaiation Australia chief executive Michael Linke said the organisation would also investigate, but the pilot's next of kin was not yet notified.
Rescuers may be hampered by the remote suburb's rough, hilly terrain about six kilometres from The Oaks Airfield, often used by recreational pilots.
Footage of the crash site shows a small green and yellow plane broke into pieces on impact.
The designer of the plane, experienced pilot Wayne Fisher of Spectrum Aviation, was himself killed when he crashed an ultralight plane in March 2013.
The two-seater Drifter Fisher Mark I Sport slammed into a the ground near Barkers Lodge Road, killing the pilot instantly
